Kali-yuga is the fourth and final cycle in the cycle of ages or Yugas in Hindu cosmology. It is believed to be the age of darkness and ignorance, characterized by moral and social decay, widespread suffering, and a general decline in spirituality. According to Hindu scriptures, Kali-yuga is marked by the loss of virtuous principles and the prevalence of greed, dishonesty, and violence. It is said to have started around 5,000 years ago and will last for a total of 432,000 years, with only 5,000 years having passed so far. Despite the challenges of Kali-yuga, it is also seen as an opportunity for personal growth and spiritual elevation.

The other three cycles in the Hindu cosmology of Yugas are:

1. Satya Yuga: Also known as the Golden Age, it is believed to be the age of truth and perfection, characterized by righteousness, virtue, and spirituality. It is said to have lasted for 1,728,000 years, and people lived in peace and harmony, following a simple and natural way of life.

2. Treta Yuga: This is the second cycle, also known as the Silver Age, characterized by a reduction in spirituality and virtue. It is said to have lasted for 1,296,000 years, and it is during this period that the concept of sacrifice was introduced, along with societal hierarchy.

3. Dwapara Yuga: The third cycle, also known as the Bronze Age, witnessed an even further decline in spirituality and virtue. It is said to have lasted for 864,000 years, and it is during this period that the great epics of Mahabharata and Ramayana were composed, marked by wars and conflicts.

Each Yuga is said to have a shorter lifespan than the previous one, indicating a gradual decline in human values and morality. It is believed that the current age of Kali Yuga started after the end of Dwapara Yuga, marking the final phase of the cycle of Yugas.

The right hemisphere kicks you in the butt, reorients you, and says "look, you're going too far, it's time to give up this delusion, return to reality, and start from scratch". There is a dynamic equilibrium between extreme delusion and extreme doubt. On the one hand, you can believe you are Napoleon and try to take over the world. On the other, life is gloomy. The framing of the left and right hemisphere in terms of self-deception is a popular idea and has been explored in various fields, including psychology and neuroscience. While some research has supported the idea that the left hemisphere tends to be more analytical and logical, while the right hemisphere is more intuitive and creative, this specific claim about self-deception is not supported by strong empirical evidence.

Furthermore, the idea that depression leads to more realistic thinking is a controversial topic in the field of psychology. While it is true that some individuals with depression may have a more negative outlook on life, it is not necessarily true that their thinking is more accurate or realistic. Clinical depression can lead to distorted thinking patterns and irrational beliefs, which can contribute to the maintenance of depressive symptoms.

Therefore, while the idea of the left and right hemisphere playing different cognitive roles is an interesting one, it is important to be cautious about making blanket statements about self-deception and realistic thinking without sufficient empirical evidence to support them.

The Suśrutasaṃhitā is an ancient Sanskrit text in the tradition of Ayurveda, which is the traditional Hindu system of medicine. The text is attributed to the ancient Indian surgeon, Sushruta, who lived in Varanasi, India around 600 BCE.

The Suśrutasaṃhitā is one of the foundational texts of Ayurveda and is divided into six books or sections, which cover a wide range of topics related to medicine and surgery, including anatomy, physiology, diseases, and treatments. The text includes detailed descriptions of surgical techniques such as rhinoplasty (nose surgery), lithotomy (surgical removal of stones from the urinary tract), and cataract surgery, among others.

The Suśrutasaṃhitā is known for its sophistication and innovation, and it was widely influential in the development of both Ayurveda and modern surgery. It had a significant impact on the practice of medicine in India and beyond, and it remains an important text in the study of Ayurveda and ancient Indian medicine.
